section_purpose: To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed framework for solving combinatorial optimization problems (Max-Cut, MIS, MDS) through experiments aimed at answering three key questions regarding transferability, incorporation of Max-SAT, and the impact of pre-training and domain adaptation strategies.
key_points: Q1: Investigates whether Max-SAT can be leveraged to learn transferable and generalizable features for solving different CO problems on graphs.
Q2: Explores how to incorporate Max-SAT into GNN-based learning frameworks to fully utilize its information.
Q3: Examines whether different pre-training and domain adaptation strategies affect the ability to solve CO problems.

algorithms: Algorithm 2: Pre-training process using a bipartite graph from Max-SAT, involving MLP initialization, feature extraction via Bip-GNN layers, prediction mapping with FC, and loss computation.
Algorithm 3: Fine-tuning based on domain adaptation, handling source and target domains separately, using a discriminator (Dis) for domain labels, and computing a combined loss.
formulas: Equations referenced: Eqs. (3.10) and (3.11) for clause-wise aggregation, Eqs. (3.12) and (3.13) for variable-wise aggregation, Eq. (3.14) for pre-training loss, Eq. (3.15) for fine-tuning loss.
architectures: MLP (Multi-Layer Perceptron) for initial node feature transformation
Bip-GNN (Bipartite Graph Neural Network) for feature extraction
FC (Fully Connected layer) for mapping to predictions
Dis (Discriminator) for domain adaptation in fine-tuning

hyperparameters.L: Number of pre-training or fine-tuning layers

dependencies: Section 3 Methodology (specifically 3.2 to 3.4 for Max-SAT transformation and learning framework)
